questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought by her father because she has been acting strangely after the death of her only brother 2 weeks ago. She stays in her brother's room most of the time and talks alone with a wall. While interviewing her alone, she suddenly turns and says: “Yes, Joseph, this is a very good question, but wait until after the examination.” Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Brief psychotic disorder A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by: Positive psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech) Typically triggered by a stressful life event Last > 1 day and ≤ 1 month Not associated with a mood disorder, a substance-related disorder, or a psychotic disorder caused by a general medical condition.

Highyeild:

The onset of symptoms in brief psychotic disorder is usually sudden (without a prodrome) and the functional impairment can be severe. After the episode, individuals gradually return to the premorbid state . For those who present with depressed mood, insomnia, anhedonia, decreased appetite, and fatigue for more than 2 weeks, it should be distinguished from a major depressive disorder with psychotic features.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A . The diagnostic criteria for Schizoaffective disorder require the presence of ≥ 2 of the following psychotic symptoms : delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, and grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior. Additionally, symptoms must be present for ≥ 2 weeks , and this patient's auditory hallucinations started only a week ago. Finally, diagnostic criteria for this condition also require that criteria for a major mood disorder are met in the periods without psychotic symptoms ; this patient has not had any period without psychotic symptoms. Option: C. Adjustment disorder can occur in response to a traumatic life event and manifest with impaired social functioning and symptoms of depressed mood , both of which are seen here. However, affected individuals do not present with the auditory hallucinations seen in this patient. Moreover, adjustment disorder is a diagnosis of exclusion , and this patient's symptoms are better explained by another psychological disorder. Option: D. Acute stress disorder can manifest with insomnia and negative mood , both of which are seen here. Furthermore, the death of a relative can be traumatic and trigger an acute stress disorder. However, this condition does not manifest with hallucinations . Moreover, in acute stress disorder affected individuals also present with intrusive symptoms (e.g., recurrent distressing memories/dreams about the traumatic event, flashbacks), dissociative symptoms (e.g., loss of memory regarding details of the event), active avoidance (i.e., avoidance of external reminders, memories, thoughts, and feelings related to the event), and other symptoms related to arousal (e.g., irritable behavior, hypervigilance), none of which is seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought by her mother because of a 4-month history of feeling sad, decreased sleep & appetite, and decreased focus at work. She says that she feels empty inside and has been hearing voices for 7 months telling her that she is worthless and making fun of her. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizoaffective disorder Schizoaffective disorder is a condition in which patients meet the clinical criteria for both schizophrenia and a major mood disorder . Patients must exhibit Psychotic symptoms for ≥ 2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode , Symptoms of a major mood disorder must be present for the majority of the duration of the illness. This patient has auditory hallucinations that started 7 months ago and disorganized speech (thought-blocking; stopping in the middle of sentences), which fulfills the criteria for schizophrenia . She also has 5 of the diagnostic depressive symptoms (depressed mood, decreased appetite, insomnia, psychomotor slowing, inability to focus) that started 4 months ago, which fulfils the criteria for major depressive disorder .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect option:- Option: A . This patient’s symptoms fulfill the criteria for schizophrenia. However, with the addition of her mood symptoms, she meets the criteria for another psychiatric diagnosis. Option: C . Psychotic symptoms in this condition appear exclusively during manic or depressive episodes. But, This patient's psychotic symptoms started 7 months ago when she first started hearing voices; her depressive symptoms began 4 months ago. Option: D. Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms that last 1–6 months . This patient's psychotic symptoms started 7 months ago when she first started hearing voices.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 2 weeks after a motor vehicle accident in which he suffered significant head trauma. His parents are concerned because the patient believes them to be imposters who have replaced his real parents. He agrees that these people look like his real parents but is convinced that they are indeed imposters. What delusion is this known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Capgras syndrome Capgras syndrome is a delusional belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an impostor.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: Option: A . Cacodemonomania is the delusion of being poisoned by an evil spirit. Option: B . Folie à deux is a delusion shared by more than one person. Option: D. The Fregoli delusion is a rare disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes appearance or is in disguise.

questions.text: A person is admitted to the psychiatry ward and whenever the doctor comes towards him, he shouts that “he is his relative who wants to kill him. He came in the disguise of a doctor to kill him.” Which Delusion is this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frégoli’s syndrome The Fregoli delusion is a rare disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes appearance or is in disguise.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an impostor. Option: C . Delusion of reference-the Patient believes that insignificant remarks and events refer to him. Option: D . The very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will (intermetamorphosis)

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes with her mother because of a 2-week history of feeling unusually energetic, often pacing around her room, and not sleeping. She had a similar episode 5 months ago. She worked as a dental technician until 6 months ago when she heard voices telling her to quit. She prefers to be alone at home. On MSE, she is alert but has pressured speech and stops midway while speaking. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizoaffective disorder Schizoaffective disorder is a condition in which patients meet the clinical criteria for both schizophrenia and a major mood disorder (depression or bipolar) . Patients must exhibit Psychotic symptoms for ≥ 2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode , Symptoms of a major mood disorder must be present for the majority of the duration of the illness. This patient has auditory hallucinations (hearing voices) that started 6 months ago and disorganized speech (thought-blocking; stopping in the middle of sentences), which fulfills the criteria for schizophrenia . She also has 4 of the diagnostic manic symptoms (unusually energetic, psychomotor agitation, pressured speech, and lack of sleep), which fulfills the criteria for bipolar disorder(mania) .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B . Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by restricted emotional expression , a preference for solitary activities , reduced affect , and indifference to praise or criticism. The only one of these features that is present in this patient is a preference for solitary activities. This disorder is also not associated with delusions . Option: C . Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by magical thinking and social anxiety. There is no history of social anxiety in this patient, as her social withdrawal could also be voluntary. Option: D. Schizophrenia can manifest with delusional thoughts , hallucinations (hearing voices), and disorganized speech (thought blocking), which are present in this patient. However, manic symptoms would be uncharacteristic of schizophrenia. Instead, negative symptoms, such as flat affect and social withdrawal, would be expected, but are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was admitted to the psychiatric ward shortly after starting military duty. During the first week after his arrival at the military base, he thought that other recruits strangely looked at him and were out "to get" him. He heard voices calling his name several times. He gave the impression of being very shy and inhibited. He had no previous psychiatric illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Brief psychotic disorder A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by: Positive psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech) Typically triggered by a stressful life event Last > 1 day and ≤ 1 month Not associated with a mood disorder, a substance-related disorder, or a psychotic disorder caused by a general medical condition.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: Option: A . Schizophrenia is the diagnosis if the symptoms last for more than 6 months. Option: C . Schizoaffective disorder can not be diagnosed as the patient has no history of mood disorder. Option: D . Schizophreniform disorder- If the duration of symptoms is between one month to 6 months.

options.label: A
options.text: The symptoms of schizophreniform are similar to those of schizophrenia; however, with schizophreniform disorder, the symptoms last for at least 1 month but less than 6 months.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The paranoid type of schizophrenia is characterized by preoccupation with one or more delusions(delusions of persecution or grandeur) or frequent auditory hallucinations.

questions.correct_answer: C. A patient with Schizoaffective disorder always has features of schizophrenia and depression only.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A patient with Schizoaffective disorder always has features of schizophrenia and depression only. Schizoaffective disorder has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders not only depression.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option A- The symptoms of schizophreniform are similar to those of schizophrenia; however, with schizophreniform disorder, the symptoms last for at least 1 month but less than 6 months is a true statement. Option B- Brief psychotic disorder is defined as a psychotic condition that involves the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, which lasts 1 day or more but less than 1 month is a true statement. Option D- The paranoid type of schizophrenia is characterized by preoccupation with one or more delusions(delusions of persecution or grandeur) or frequent auditory hallucinations is a true statement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought by his wife because of bizarre and agitated behavior for the last 6 weeks. He thinks that someone is spying on him and controlling his mind. His wife reports that the patient has become withdrawn and at times depressed and stopped going to work for the past 3 months. On MSE, his speech is disorganized and his affect is labile. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizophreniform disorder Schizophreniform disorder is a clinical diagnosis that is made using the same diagnostic criteria as schizophrenia ( present with delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or negative symptoms that impair social, occupational, and personal functioning). The main difference, however, is the duration of the disorder is less than 6 months . If symptoms persist for > 6 months , the diagnosis must be changed to schizophrenia .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A . Although this patient's clinical presentation is consistent with schizophrenia, psychotic symptoms must last > 6 months in order to make this diagnosis. Option: C. Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by features of schizophrenia AND major mood disorder (depression or bipolar disorder). Psychotic symptoms must be more dominant than mood symptoms, and while psychosis can occur in the absence of mood disorders, mood disorders do not occur in the absence of psychosis. This patient showed a depressed mood before the onset of psychotic symptoms. Furthermore, psychosis must have been present for at least 2 weeks without any mood disturbance to make the diagnosis. Option: D. Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms lasting > 1 day but ≤ 1 month , and are usually triggered by stressful situations . This patient's psychotic symptoms began 6 weeks ago.

questions.text: A 48-year-old was brought to the hospital by his son as he noticed behavioral changes in his father for 2-3 months, where he believes that he is a very successful and rich businessman. He started throwing stones and garbage at the neighbor’s house as he feels that they are trying to steal his ideas and property and trying to harm him and take away everything from him. The patient is a case of-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delusional disorder The given case history suggests a Delusion of persecution where the person is afraid that the neighbors are trying to harm him. It is a classic symptom of delusional disorder ; persecutory-type and jealousy-type delusions are probably the forms seen most frequently by psychiatrists.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Schizophrenia may be associated with hallucinations, negative emotions, grossly disorganized/catatonic behavior, or disorganized speech . The given case history depicts only delusional symptoms. Option: C. Mania is a mood disorder in which the patient appears to be over-enthusiastic with heightened emotions . Delusion of grandiosity is usually associated with Mania. Option: D. Schizophreniform disorder would have similar symptoms to Schizophrenia but with a duration of presentation being 1-6 Months .

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is brought to the hospital by her mother as she was seen crying continuously for over 4-5 days and had reduced sleep and low mood for 2 months. The mother even noted her talking to herself at times. On questioning, she replies that she hears voices that command her to die and voices talking amongst themselves for almost 7 months. She feels that she isn’t worthy of staying alive. The patient is diagnosed as-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizoaffective disorder Schizoaffective disorder is a condition in which patients meet the clinical criteria for both schizophrenia and a major mood disorder (depression or bipolar) . Patients must exhibit Psychotic symptoms for ≥ 2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode , Symptoms of a major mood disorder must be present for the majority of the duration of the illness.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: Option: A. Schizophrenia can manifest with delusional thoughts , hallucinations , and disorganized speech , which are present in this patient. However, depressive mood symptoms would be uncharacteristic of schizophrenia. Option: B & C. Depression and Bipolar disorder with psychotic features can be considered but are not diagnosed as primary illnesses as psychotic symptoms were present for more than 2 weeks without mood features in this patient which is characteristic of schizoaffective.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought by his mother. For 2 months, he has been hitting his school friends and doesn’t respond when called or punished by the teacher. There were 2 episodes when he suddenly started screaming in between class hours. He isn’t eating or sleeping properly. He also keeps talking to himself at times and on enquiry points towards the wall saying his friends are standing there. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizophreniform disorder The duration of the presentation is 2 months (1-6 months) and the boy has hallucinations and negative symptoms of schizophrenia . Hence it is a Schizophreniform disorder.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Schizophrenia is diagnosed if the symptoms given in the above case are present for at least 6 months (DSM-5) Option: B. Schizoaffective disorder is when Schizophrenia is associated with mood disorders. In the given history negative symptoms are mentioned not mood alterations. Option: C. Oppositional Defiant Disorder is a behavioral disorder in children. Such children would not have an acute history of hallucinations as in the above-mentioned case.

questions.text: Family members bring a patient to your psychiatry OPD with complaints of sudden onset of psychotic symptoms in the last 4 days. You conclude it to be a Brief Psychotic Disorder. The statements given below are all true concerning the condition except:

options.label: A
options.text: Brief psychotic disorder is defined as a psychotic condition that involves the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, which lasts 1 day or more but less than 1 month.

options.label: B
options.text: Remission is full, and the individual returns to the premorbid level of functioning.

options.label: C
options.text: The disorder occurs more often among older patients than among younger patients.

options.label: D
options.text: Brief psychotic disorder is more common in women than in men

questions.correct_answer: C. The disorder occurs more often among older patients than among younger patients.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The disorder occurs more often among older patients than among younger patients. Brief psychotic disorder (BPD) according to DSM-5 is the sudden onset of psychotic behavior that lasts less than 1 month followed by complete remission with possible future relapses . It is differentiated from schizophreniform disorder and schizophrenia by the duration of the psychosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option A - Brief psychotic disorder is defined as a psychotic condition that involves the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, which lasts 1 day or more but less than 1 month is a true statement. Option B- Remission is full, and the individual returns to the premorbid level of functioning is a true statement. Option D - Brief psychotic disorder is more common in women than in men.
